element_texts.text: Completed

mother - Milo, Nov. 25. / 52
Du Quoin - Dec 25 - 1852

                                                                                                               Milo Nov 25th 1852

My Dear Children 

   We receiv'd your good letters of Oct 28th in due Season & thank you very much I Suppose you are before now at Du Quoin _____ I can write the word after a fashion, But I am Sure I dont know how to pronounce it do please tell me in your next
    Tis Thanksgiving Day I've just return'd from meeting been to hear Squeaking Mr. White preach a very good Sermon the only Congregationalist Sermon that I have heard in Milo for a long long time & we have no prospect of any - ever again as I know of The meeting house they Say will be done in about two weeks they think to dedicate it new years. I feel interested in it as I should in any thing regarding the cause of religion _____ But none the more for its being in this town as I know of I hardly know why I feel so indiferant about it. I suspect it is "Cas I'se wicked"
    Charles has got an "addition" in the shape of a fine fat little daughter weighing 9 lb 6 ounces it was born 2 oclock in the morning Saturday. 20th Monday morning Albina walk'd across her room with it in her arms today she is all about in the kitchen
    Lucy unclear is here for a visit of a few days they have all been here Since she mov'd  away but it Seems a great long way up there they Seem all very comfortable and happy the mail goes not till saturday so I'll put my letter by till tomorrow
Completed

26th
Fruit is very plenty about here Apples especially Charles bought Some apples on the trees out in Sebec gave 3 dollars pick'd them himself had 60 or 70 bushels he kept George here till the first of this month. he has nobody with him now is killing a Beef today

     He has met with quite a loss his beautiful great new Colt she got a peice of hard Tooth of a horse rake wood an inch square & 16 inches long run clean into her side so far that it was with difficultly Charles could get hold of it with the pincers to pull it out she was a beautiful beast & fat as a hog the very day before, Charles was saying that he should not be willing to take $125.00 for her he was gone away when it was done & it remain'd in her side about 4 hours before he knew it went in thro' her ribs broke 2 or 3 of them & the wonder of it is she is alive yet 3 weeks ago it was done. He begins to think there is a possiblity of her getting well but of course never be good for much It was sad tho' but a beast to see her Suffer so_______Hay is 15,00 a ton about here now [not press'd] C. Sold his 4 or 5 tons to Sam'l sometime ago for 12,00_________Pork, Corn, Hay and every thing is so high this fall it will make it bad for Sam'l he & Mr Bradeen have unclear men (Six teams) in the woods he was up round about here last Friday a week ago buying Oxen & Flay he said he should have sav'd 125,00 just on the Corn he had got to buy if he had got it 2 or 3 weeks sooner____Charles's Corn got ripe & is very good
         I hope you will not be disappointed in your expectations in regard to Society at Du Quoin however I dont want you should like so well as unclear you will feel willing to stay longer than is very necessary I am expecting to go to Bangor
Completed

Sometime this winter shall perhaps stay till April or May

      The weather has been very mild and pleasant this fall & I have got along quite comfortably with the Old airtight____have been in my room alone a great deal of the time Tis rather profitable for me I think as solitude with me facilitates an acquaintance with self perhaps I might not be quite contented if compell'd to be much alone but I could you know (and Have availed myself of the privelege) have the company of Albina & the noise & fun of the children whenever I chose Charles has been so busy that I have not seen much of him except at Meals his evenings when at home have been taken up in husking Corn &c &c Henry Thomson has return'd from California with poor health William Halman & Ichabod Mitchel have died there__________I like very much to stay at Bangor as many accounts more of my Children are there & it is _______________pleasanter in many respects But I feel that this is my home and where I ought to be there seems a propriety in old people retiring from the world and communing with there own hearts and tho' it may not be universally the case yet as a general thing (there is no disputing it) the company of old people is not acceptable or agreeable to the young in some instances not even to their own___I consider myself among the highly favor'd was ever so undeserving a creature so exeedingly bless'd with the very kindest & best of Children & that they should all ___every one be so good
Completed

I think you are in favorable circumstances to feel what we all ought to feel that you are strangers and Pilgrims on the earth ___________ I should think you could not really feel at home while boarding about so & I dont quite want you should till you get back to M. England - yet I do suppose that is a better region in many respects than this cold corner of the world -------- If my children could all be located near each other and I could be with them I should not care very much where 

   I had calculated that I should have an highly favorable time this fall & winter here alone (almost) to read & think & really hoped to grow better ---- But what with various little jobs of work for the Children &c. The petty cares & [[unclear] of hindrances and the rambling [[unclear] thoughts. I have made no progress as I can see but remain the same bad comodity as ever---I desire to avoid looking at or thinking of Self for I find no comfort in it --- But in looking to the ever blessed merciful Saviour of Sinners there is comfort, there is joy unspeakable joy --- I do hope that I have an interest in Christ --- but if it is a well grounded hope why am I not more like him why am I so very far from being like him ---- Strive my Children now while you are young while "life is before you, to make great attainments in holiness & may the god of all grace never forsake you but be with you in goodness & mercy all the way in which you go from your affectionate Mother A.M.M.
Completed

Mother M. Bangor Jan.03/1853
Du Quoin Feb - 1853
Bangor Jan. 6th 1853
My Dear Children
Here I am at Bangor again in the nice new house - & with a gold pen writing a letter - We didn't have gold pens to write with when I was young but must be endebted (sic) to the old goose - I am keeping house all alone except Jane Sam'l has gone into the wood, to be gone 10 day, or more & Anna & Lucy are gone with him as far as Milo & Brownville to visit till he comes back - I expected that Elilab would be here with me but the very day that they went away he had a "telegram, from Boston informing him that the Brig Susan Duncan had arriv'd & he started right off at 6- in the evening - He has gone to sell the the (sic) Brig if he can I believe he said that he own'd 3/4 or 7/8 I don't know which he is to sell the whole at his discretion
Lucy, health is good for her - She can not stand & walk as she us'd to but her appetite is very good - I have some peas that her journey
Completed

will be to (sic) hard for her - they rode in a "Puny" (sic) that Sam'l got made on purpose for his convenience about going into the woods this winter,
he is driving about at a great rate tho' as usual he is very quiet & still about it - I suppose the profits of his Mill this year are 2000,$ and he will make or lose a good deal this winter by his Lumbering opperation (sic)-
By dint of great exertion he succeeded in getting supplys (sic) to his men & teams so that they did n't (sic) absolutely suffer but several others had to drive their teams out it was so late before the lakes were frozen so that they could 
over          Eliab has lately return'd from Easthamton (sic) he went first to Mathfield Montagne & Warrick found the folks all well Moriah Stevens & her Mother have settled down on the old Homestead - She is teaching in the brick school house this winter - He also visited at Montford with his Maria had a very pleasant time he say, they expect to be married in the spring I guess
I wish I could know that I shall love Maria as well as I do Antoinnette - I don't know any reason why I shall not - cannot know till
Completed

I see her - However I shall love her because E. does if for no other reason
Mr. Gilman River & his wife were at Monson lately to attend the county conference I expect they will be at Brener [?] next week he is a Delegate to the [?] Conference - & we shall have a visit from them
The new Meeting house at Milo was dedicated 28th of Dec. - Charles attend Singing school Monday & Tuesday evening of every week is their chief Singer in the Choir & much engaged in it devotes too much time to it I tell him considering his age he needs more time for reading & meditation - We are reading "Voices of Nature tis excellent but almost to strong for me to digest readying "milk for babes' you know
I wrote you how Charles has got a little Daughter I don't know what her name will be perhaps Mary
I rejoice that you are so favor'd about preaching what a blessing it is
have just been interrupted by a call from Mrs. Martin our next door neighbor whom I never saw before I hoped that the people wouldn't find out that I was alone - I love to be alone sometimes
Completed

I enjoy reading so much better when I am alone that I find I must set a guard upon myself or my eyes will complain of me
I wish you would tell me what you think of the Albany Convention and the controversy between Congregationalists and Presbyterians if it may be call a controversy which I hope will result  in greater love and zeal for the cause of Christ by all everywhere - But O  how much harder it does seem to be to promote the cause of truth than that of error -  because men love darkness better than light
How very little the light of Christ does shine in his profess'd followers to what it ought to I have hoped thro' mercy infinite and glorious that Christ is mine and I am his but O how all my life has seem'd to contradict it
God bless you my dear children and incline your hearts to all good and to pray for you,
Mother  A.N.M.
Completed

Mother to Bangor (unclear) (unclear)
                                                                                                                                                                                                         March 26, 1853
My Dear Children, First I must thank you more especially My Nettie tho you are both one- for a very beautiful Book Mark it is in modern phrase exquisitely Elegant
    I intended to have written to you again before now but being here and having in some men have the care of cooking and household affairs seems to absorb about what little i have left of mind and thought-- However I enjoy it---- when you can get the girls letters as a substitute for mine you'll be great  (unclear) by it you know for I am  growing old & stupid or rather I am grown old and stupid --- only think now I am 66 years old. And what has my life been ? if I could not throw it all away and flee to Christ as a hiding place  and (unclear), how miserable I should be I had a letter from your Uncle at  (unclear) a few days since           He said he had been sick but is getting better your uncle Enoch perhaps you know has had a shock of  paralysis cannot use his right hand feeds and shaves himself with his left    Eliab has I suppose told you of  the " Brig Susan Duncan's " Disaster her Master carried away  He making a Bill of 2 or 3000.00  for her owner.  Eliab is more  unfortunate than he  (unclear) to be his health so poor these two years past

(left side of page and top )
does not as a gift, but rather as a matter of rights , it would be more agreeable to her feelings with out doubt__  If we are wrong in the matter why then do nothing about it. I have said nothing  E as he has unusual expense about this time. In haste  Most affectionately, Sister Lucy
Completed

And I believe he saw that his not worth any more than he was 2 years ago he is boarding now on Essex Street with a Mrs Ureys gives $3.50 a week his health is better than it was last fall but he is not strong I think he could not perform more than one quarter of the labor he used to in a day yet if he is careful of himself he may be entirely well again after a while
Charles is getting along about as usual I suppose, he has no hired help this winter nobody in the house but himself & wife & the babies
I very much enjoy that you are so favorably circumstanced in regard to society and religious privileges So much better than in any of us expected
Mrs. Crosby seems very anxious & yet very happy about William She says he like his business very much & "thinks every thing of Mr. Metcalf & his wife"
Is he efficient and smart and likely to make a good Engineer? What compensations does he have?
Eliab had just been in here say they have just a telegram from M. York informing that the Hartford had lost all his rigging which will make him another bill of 5 or 6 hundred dollars, but he seems quite cheerful about it. He show'd us a list of Books you had sent for. Why my son do buy so many Books & Periodicals? unless you buy them to give away I should think they would be rather an incumbrance. as you are migratory. If you much read them all I should agree with Proff Sheppard that the more you have of them the worse off you are
Completed

You know that Mr. Lee & Mr. Sargent & yourself are the only male members of the Church in Milo. Mr. Sargent the only resident? member. Mr. L & S have I suppose given Almeda & her daughter Lucy a letter of unclear unclear]] to the Brownville Chruch & Mr. Lee & wife as I understood are about to remove their unclear to Brownville Church
Have you anything to do in the unclear as regards yourself before the Church becomes quite extinct as it very probably it will. The meeting house built by Mr. Owen for the use of the Baptist Church has already become a bone of contention. It was proposed that the Baptist buy half the unclear & the unclear Baptist the other half & that would pay Mr. Owen. But the 2 parties cannot agree about the control of it. The Freewill Baptist want to let the unclear have the privilege of having it with them & the Colonial Baptist are not willing they should. 
I wish you could have heard a Lecture unclear Sheppard delivered lately on reading He compared novel reading to pouring Dishy? dirty water thro a sieve just for the unclear while it passes there. Some people's reading like the unclear of a lumber unclear compose of all manner of commodities & then bumbled from the unclear into the cellar in comparison many unclear things there but is passable when wanted the more one has the verse off unclear I wish I could tell you more that he said but if I could I could not tell it as he did & I don't know if any body that could he is a powerful man Everett calls him the old sledge hammer
Completed

Dear Brother Isaac
I only put in a few words on unclear before this letter is sealed up. unclear are unclear that our Mother, like most other people in this world, occasionally want these a little filthy lucre. She as little probably as most people As it was our brother Joseph's request that she should receive something from his property if needed. I think it would be extremely gratifying to her if you would write to Samuel authorizing him to hand her 50 or 100 dollars (I believe he is owning unclear, so that she can have a stone of her own to go with our being dependent upon two, three, or five dollars at a time as she needs to use it. If you think of it you will perceive that with her unclear and independent feelings it would be much pleasanter. She really wants to go to the Majs next summer & I think ought to go - of course will need some fitting out. do not write in answer to thia as Anna & I have conferred together & write accordingly, but as if it were your own thoughts and wish. Such a unclear would last her a long time you know-and if you
Completed

Written in darker ink at top:
Mother M. Bangor May 8, 1853
DuQuoin Ills. May 27, 1853
Bangor May 8th/53
My Dear Children
I suppose I Sam'l write to you a few days ago informing you of the fact that on his birthday - being the 2nd of May he had a valuable present - no less than a fine healthy beautiful Son weighing nine pounds - the babe is still doing well - And Lucy is getting along finely so much better than we had any reason to expect that you may well suppose we are all very joyful and I hope thankful - We have a Mrs. Griffith from Brownville here in the capacity of nurse (she is Mr John Thomas's Daughter) who with Anna and myself make quite a valuable trio for taking care of Lucy and baby - indeed Anna is a [?] in herself you don't know how good and doing good and unselfish she is - Well now really are not my sons & my sons wife, all my Daughters and my Daughter's husband, about the best folks in the wide
Written up the left side and across the top:
Lucy sits up just long enough to have her bed made appetite is pretty good - if she can only get rid of that weakness in her back I think she may be a stout? healthy woman - but that troubles her considerably now 
written upside down:
Keep us informed of your welfare - let us know of all your joys & sorrows if you have any
Completed

world, - at any rate I don't know but I must be permitted to think so - Sam'l is one of the best of folk. So perfectly sincere and honest in all he does & says - So rich in good works (as well as in other ways) devising liberal things - he gives this year $4,00 a month for Foreign Missions and liberally for the Support of preaching building meeting house &c &c And he can the better afford to do as he has I think a very excellent faculty to "put money in his purse
Do you know anything of Mr. Philo Carpenter of Chicago - The School that Anna and Lizzie expect to engage in will be in a sense under his patronage He wrote to them not long since that on account of building a house for the school it would be advisable for them not to commence till September So you see Anna will not [?] last of August at which we are very glad as she has not yet spent any time hardly with Almeda
You enquire what you had better do about your relation to the Church in Milo the only members of which I believe are Mr. Sargent & wife Mrs Doct. Kimnball Mr. Stubs
Completed

and you and I - Mr. S. says now that he shall not remove his relation to Brownville and I am inclin'd to think I had better not - Tis an unpleasant state of things - I don't know what your duty is about it - I should very much prefer to be united with a strictly Congregational Church rather than a Presbyterian - If you were permanently located in that place Du Quoin I should not like to advise you not to unite with that church as there is no other there indeed I don't feel competent to advise in the matter at all but I feel a little as if you had better do nothing about it just at present
I should be very glad to tell you something about Eliabs wife but I have seen so little of her that I do not feel enough acquaintance to say much about her - She is a very little body seems to be very pleasant, unassuming, affectionate, and very Ladylike - they have call'd here 3 times in the evening I have scarcely seen Eliab to speak with him besides since he got back - He is very busy nowadays in his shingle business - We had a letter from Lucy Searles  a few days ago - Mr. Humphrey  you know is gone from Foxcroft - Mr. Butterfield is
Completed

principal there I think it is not a very good school at present from Lucy's description of it. Do you recollect the scandalous stories about Mr. unclear Parker and Abby Foss 5 ot 6 years ago. They are married again it seem it is very strange & I should think very unclear about I hope they will not hinder his usefulness. Sam'l has been buying fruit tress & Brumbleberry gooseberry raspberry & unclear bushes for his garden. There seems to be a great zeal for gardening & fruit in this city. A Mr. Somebody gave 50, 00 for 5 plum tress a few days ago. I've all send love as much as we can spare from the little precious one. I almost forgot to tell you his name.. P.P. Furber ie Pierce Power. The diminutive or baby name will be, probably, Percy
Anna has know rather more of Maria than the rest of us she says that she seems to make a very favorable impression on those who have call'd on her. unclear Sheppard & wife and Mrs. Jenkins have been somewhat acquainted with her Father. The position of E & M in society here is probably rather flattering at present--which may perhaps work rather unfavorable in unclear to his unclear interest as he will neither be likely to adopt a unclear of living which he can handily afford unless his health should be pretty good, or be very unclear in business both may be & are likely for ought & know we can hardly expect to have much of him at present he is so completely absorb'd with his new business
Completed

Mother June 25, 1853
Milo Maine
DuQuoin July 9 1853
Milo June 24th 1853
My Dear Dear Children - I've receiv'd letter yesterday A Son & heir hey! Well I rejoice truly sincerely - exceedingly - and thankfully - especially that the Mother & child are doing well - but allow me to be in some anxiety lest they should not continue so, for it seems to me hardly possible for Nettie in that warm Climate to nurse & take care of her babe and feel well as she could here  I hope that the next news I hear from you will not be that she is sick -- You will I trust be very careful of them both - & yourself too -- A name - well I suppose the dear little one (O how I do want to see it) must have a name it must be a difficult matter to decide I really dont know how you can determine unless you call it Michael (Mike) or unclear name
However it is not much matter what the name is no doubt he'll do honor to it - whatever it may be if he lives - O if I had wings like a dove how quick I would be with you
Long before this will reach you you will have had the sad news of our affliction in the death of our dear Lucy - But how far different & how exceedingly more distressing would be our feelings if we mourn'd as those with out hope  I really do not know the person in whose death we could have stronger consolation - Always So much purity of thought and 
Written up the left side:
I cant find a pen unclear to write with - to say nothing about paper
but if you can read it tis no matter
Completed

feeling so little desire or care for the fashions and follies of the world
I had a good letter from Maria yesterday she is a really good little person. Eliab has really got a very good wife I do think & I think so more & more, I like her very much better than I expected - How thankful I ought to be (hope I am some) that you & Eliab are so bless'd
Eliab has made me "Member of the Maine Miss Society and Sam'l has made Lucy a Member also are not they good boys - Anna is at Brownville will probably be there about two weeks longer then she rather espects to be here till about the first of august & to start for Chicago the middle of August
The season has been very favorable the Crops look better than usual vegetation earlier by about 2 weeks than common C. says he has never seen so much grain on the ground at this time of the year since he has liv'd here as now, he has 3 acres of Corn & potatos planted three acres of wheat & oats and three acres of Buckwheat - he has a young man at work for him 17 years old brother to Mrs. Ricker - middling good help.
Lucy Searles had been at Foxcroft School the last term was very fleshy & healthy when she went but I guess she studied hard (she never could learn easy as mu children could) and she had a poor boarding place - At Mr. Pauls was too retiring and bashful didn't get enough of decent and wholesome food to eat for some time before she returned was not well probably more unwell than she was aware of herself  She wrote that she wants to come home but they did not get the letter at first her Father went after her about a week before school clos'd they called her and took dinner & said nothing about
Completed

being unwell but soon after she got home she had unclearsevere pain in her head & only a day or two after was depriv'd of her reason and except at short intervals while she liv'd which was only 2 weeks - Anna & I were both at Bangor with Lucy Anna went to Bronsville the Monday before she died monday & I only arriv'd there a few hours before she breath'd her last - She could not speak to me but I think she knew me She died 30th of May I stay'd there till the next Sabbath - have been up since and stay'd a week  - carried Charlie up there to stay 4 or 5 weeks and go to school with Lissie - I have been making pants jackets & Sacques for Charlie Josie & James &c &c - find enough to do but sometimes I think I do not find leisure & time to read enough
I used to imagine I should come to a time by and by when I could rest & read & think and grow better - But - I dont see as I get any nearer to it I fear I grow worse instead of better - Tho' I do think I feel more interest, care, and love for others than I us'd to
I cannot but feel considerable anxiety for you and your family this warm weather how will you get thro' july & august O how I wish you could be here during the hot weather.
I dont wonder that the woman thought it was powerful bad for Nettie  Couldn't you so arrange business as to leave a while in the hottest of the weather you know if you get sick you must leave wouldn't it be better to leave just before I would be on the lookout & do that at any rate if you find it necessary for the health of any of you
The trees you & Charles set in front of the house seem very thrifty & growing much all but one little one - C has got his paint & oil & expects to paint the house and finish the
Completed

chamber & perhaps put on Blinds to the windows this summer & fall - If I go to Mass. I think I shall go when Anna goes in August & if I can will persuade C. to to(sic) New York in Sept. or first of Oct. and come back with me I think it would do him a great deal of good he says he had better not go because it would make him discontented when he comes back he never goes away even as far as Bangor but it makes him feel that he dont want to live here - He never has been fully contented here do you think he'll live along so till he dies or move off somewhere when he gets to be an old man if he lives  Eliab had some expectation of purchasing land in Pennsylvania & Charles was all agog for going there if he did E. has probably written you all about it
I receiv'd a letter awhile ago from Mr. George B. Newton of Marblehead Mass. requesting information respecting a Deed of the Farm that your Father owned in Boyalston - Now own'd by him by virtue of his grand Fathers will - Says he cannot find the Deed among his grandfathers papers nor any registry of it at the office  I have just written a letter to him - and I unclear given him a Clue by which he can find it - thank to your arduous labor & night vigils in arranging and filing away my old papers so nicely a few years ago which enables me to do it "good boy well done" - I hope you'll give my little grandson a name let us know what it is soon - I suppose it to be very "fortunate" if he inherits his Mothers disposition as it would be so much better than any thing he could inherit from his Father however that may be I expect he'll be unclear smart young unclear God be with you & bless you my children
Completed

Written in a different handwriting on top:
Cedar Grove Aug 30, 1853
Mother M
Du Quoin Aug 16. 1853
Cedar Grove July 30th - 1853
My Dear Children  your really good refreshing letter Dated july 10 I receiv'd last monday another from Nettie to Anna receiv'd yesterday - Many Many thanks for your good letters - what should we do without them I can't not but feel anxious about you this hot weather am so rejoiced to hear that you are all well  I pray God it may continue. Tis near night & the wind blows in so cool I must get up and shut down the window  I am so glad the dear little one is goodnatur'd tis so much easier for it. Mother I should naturally expect it would be good natur'd  Our baby little Mary has been very indeed fretful and troublesome - Has the little "Son & Heir" not got a name yet? well call him. du Coigne  if that pleases you I like well -- We i.e. Anna & I think of going to Bangor in a few days - you have known her plan about a school at Chicago - It seems now to be somewhat frustrated it seems by a letter received a few days since from Mr. Carpenter that the house intended for her school is burn'd down & he writes that no other can be had immediately but invited them to go to his house till one can be procur'd  A. thinks it some uncertain about succeeding to her wishes there but is decided in this -  If she teaches any more prefers the West  Moreover Mrs. Hopkins has written 3 letters to her urging her vehemently to visit and stop 3 or 4 weeks at Elyria It would seem that she has a project of some sort which she thinks would be much to Anna's advantage but I don't tell what it is.
Completed

Mrs. H. has indicated by a mutual friend that Anna was going to C. & would pass Elyria
Now I must let you into a bit of a secret known only to 2 or 3 of us - Anna & Lucy have been engag'd by Snatches during the winter and spring in writing a kind of narrative of a persons life shaded and colored with fictitious names which they think might possibly amount to something if published possibly it might become a book as there seems to be a taste for all sorts of reading - want your & Nettie's criticism & help to polish & finish - especially yours about ways & means to get published &c. A. think now that she shall go on West as she has intended & perhaps will find some opportunity that suits her for teaching - They have got about 200 pages of manuscript of this narrative but you are solemnly enjoin'd not to mention or allude to it in any of your letters you will at once see the propriety of so doing as it may prove all a failure & they don't want Sam or Eliab or anyone to know - When Anna gets out as far as Chicago if she finds nothing north stopping for she may perhaps proceed onward & bring up with you could she be useful to you in office or "nursery so as to pay her board in the winter? while she avails herself of your & Nettie's help in her undertaking'
I think of going when A does as far as Boston & from there alone to N. or W. & am hoping that Charles will go to Warrick in Sept. & come home with me. I suppose he cannot spend long time - Tis doubtful whether I can go to N. Hampshire Should be very glad to see you Father & Mother
Completed

Anna wants you Should write to her as soon as convenient and direct to Elyria Ohio where she will probably be by the time a letter would reach there from you after you receive this. Lucy Sam'l & the fat baby have been up to see us came up last Monday returned Thursday. Almeda & Lissie came down here to see them Lucy is quite fleshy and seems to be well - only she has a constant headache. Neuralgia perhaps very severe at times mostly more side of her head Eliab has been sick with disentairy but is better now He has not been here at Milo since you were last summer. It seems that he & Maria are as happy as happy as happy can be but I tell 'em it is not good to carry on so much joking with one another as they do. However they are very sensible folks- but she "is too little" She is as much smaller than Antoinette as she is smaller than some great women. I have been told that the best goods are wrapped up in the smallest parcels. I have been not very well this 2 or 3 weeks past bad cold at first - have not been sick only lazy and useless Aug 1st Tomorrow Anna & I expect to go to Bangor. My home can hardly be call'd home I am gone from it so much three fourths of the time I guess these 2 years past. This is a secluded lovely & pleasant place in the Summer - in the winter it is rather dreary - and the society & religious privileges what are they. I think it probable that Mr. Billington who has return'd onto his farm with plenty of money and wants good house to live in- would like to buy this
Completed

Farm. He told Charles the other day (only in joke perhaps) that he would give him 1200 for it and pay him the money that day. C think he would given 1500, as if he live or his unclear unclear build a house next spring which would cost him 1000 or more i.e. to build as good or better a house. What do you think how Charles better try any to trade I like this place and hate to have him sell it. But C would be a very different and a better man in some other place & society. I've unclear had a very dry season. Hay not so good as was expected corn & other grain pretty good C has got most done staying? will finish this week has been offered 125, for unclear think not best to sell her hill of all strawberries, raspberries & blueberries are very plenty. Anna often speaks of the good time she & Nettie had last summer. Our baby tho' she has been terribly crass is very forward and smart has unclear a good which climbs up by things & make by chairs will run along I guess before she is nine months old which will be the 20th of this month. I suppose you feel quite interested about all the babies now that you have one of your own. O how I wish you could all be here a month or 2 now
May God protect & guide & keep you from all harm
Your affectionate Mother A.M.M.
Completed

Mother - Warwick Sept 3 1853
Du Quoin Ills. Sept 24 1853
Sept 3rd 1853 Warwick Mass.
My Dear Children
Here I am in Sister Conants quiet parlor. I left Bangor a week ago last Monday | August 25th | in company with Eliab & his wife & daughter Anna. E came to Boston on business & to take care of us his wife went on to visit her friends at East Hampton & Anna went on her way to Westfield where she was to stop a day or to then to Ellyria to visit Mrs Hopkins 2 or 3 weeks & then to Chicago where she will doubtless engage in teaching with encouraging prospects of success & trust. It seems rather sad to me for her at her age to go way to far from home seeking her fortune. I think it most likely her other enterprise that I wrote something about will be given all up as there are a good many difficulties in the way.
Lucy has been sorely afflicted with headache these 3 months past but is much relieved we all think she owes it to Homeophathy. I feasted my eyes almost to surputing, altho' we past it so rapidly, with with the beautiful, the romantic & the grand scenery between Boston & Northfield you have seen it and do not need a description & I could not give it if you did.
How retir'd and isolated Warwick is there is no Stage at all rune thro' the town now. Our friends here all seem "well to do in the world" indeed the people here
Completed

all seem so independent - have so few or know so few call to Charity or any thing to bring out benevolent feelings that they seem to me to be all bound about with ten thousands bands of - what shall I call it? No it is not exactly perniciousness??
Sister Conant 72 years attends to her household duties & knits stockings to sell to provide herself with the little pittance of spending money that she needs - your unclear Conant 78 years old works as steady in the fields as Harvey does & I suppose does about as much- has lately been these hots days about a mile from home on foot to work all day "picking up" on burnt land which they are clearing for rye.I spent a day or two at Albert Parson's I think he & Joseph are a little different from some here - but I have not seen Joseph he had lately moved to Brattleborough in a depot there. I have some little expectation that Charles will come here to go home with me.
I began this some day ago but have no prospect of getting it to the P.O. till the week comes round. Harvey had been quite sick a few days past - his health is not very good & his good wife worries and talks to him so much about- that perhaps it makes him more low spirits. She is afraid to have her baby most 5 years old step off the door stone hill the dew is off of without a blanket on if it is at all foggy. She is excessively careful. 
It had been exceedingly warm weather here a week or ten days past. How I do want to know how you all are am very much afraid you have all been sick with it very hard for Antoinette to take care of the dear little one & isn't it very hard for him I should think
Completed

that august must be a very trying month. O how I do wish you could get through there and come on to some of these N. England roads where the climate is such as you have been use'd to. Are you not doing more than you or any other one man ought to do so much labor and so much care is as unclear it to much. I know day you mean to be careful & I suppose you do-but I cannot help feeling anzious about you - what is the unclear about the baby's name is it Mayo or [{unclear]] I wish I could see him what is the color of his eyes in he fat does Nettie nurse him & does she have support enough for him or does she have to feed him. How long do you expect to be employed where you are you will come home next Summer if not before shant you
May God be with you and bless you A.M.M.
Completed

I began this some day ago but I have no prospect of getting it to the unclear till the next week comes round -- Harvey has been quite sick a few day past -- his health is not very good & his good wife worries and talks to him so much about - that perhaps it makes him more low spirited &c - She is afraid to have her baby most 5 years old step off the doorstone till the dew is off or without a blanket on it if is at all foggy  She is excessively careful
It has been exceedingly warm weather here a week or ten days past - How I do want to know how you all are am very much afraid you have all been sick isn't it very hard for Antoinette to take care of the dear little one & is n't it very hard for him I should think
Completed

brother? N. Milo Oct 1853
Du Quoin Nov 3, 1853
Milo
My Dear Children I suppose one this you've had unclear proof that Miss E.A. unclear is no more and have seen Mrs DeWitt. How strange it is I can hardly believe it- it seems like a dream to me-when she first wrote me that she was to be married in just a week or two, I did have a real hearty cry I was so overwhelm'd and confounded with the strange news and so I have not a child left. It is well. I must soon pass away, I can heartily rejoice that I can leave my children each unclear with a friend and companion to comfort and bless them on the journey of life. 
It seems as far as she can judge from her letters that Anna has a prospect of being very pleasantly situated. So write to us all abut the man how you like him and everything that you can think that would make us acquainted with their unclear circumstances and prospects, more than all I want to know your opinions of the man.
I return'd from Mass 1st of Oct. Had a good time am very glad I went I did not visit about much only to see Sisters Spent 2 weeks at you Aunt Conants one at Aunt Hannahs one with Aunt
Completed

Esther at you Uncle William's, spent 2 days with the people on the Brock Warwick seems a lonely almost deserted place all growing up to woods and blueberry bushes. Maria Stevens lives there on the old farm carries it on to pretty good advantage I guess and takes care of her mother who is very much broken down and silly and was sick when I was there but when well does a great deal of work. unclear hats enough to amount to 25 dollars at 5 or 10 cents a piece for braiding she is as close and loving as if there was danger of starving if they did not save & keep to herself every half cent. Maria is smart & energetic buying & selling like any farmer had no hired man when I was there but took care of her horse & cattle & every thing herself. Joseph is gone to Brattleborough I regret that I couldn't see him. I did not see Humphrey. I did see Andelia?& her lame son a short time, they came out to sister Conants he is in a most pitiable condition unable to walk these four years running unlcear constantly on both his legs tis a wonder he had lived so long but they think he is getting a little better now. 
I saw Esther Goddard & her husband & children at her fathers
Completed

What grand romantic Magnificent scenery there is on the way from Fitchburg to Northfield and the Rive dancing along first on one side then on the other is there the lake any where else South Orange is a beautiful little village I waited there an hour for the Cars on my return. They talk that the directors of the R.R. and all are satisfied now that the road ought to have been laid thro' Warwick that it could have been made and supported with much less expensive and sav'd the expense of the other road, etc. etc.   Lucy is quite well compared to what she has been these 2 or 3 years walks all about the house like any body & out in the street some
Sam'l is going into the lumbering strong this coming winter. He & Eliab are very much engag'd and doing a good deal in the Temperance Cause they both belong to a company of 40 or more Volunteer Watchman to prevent liquer being landed there,  a many other deeds of Dancing S & E went down into the hold of a vessel in a dark night without a light & roll'd out casks of Rum got hold of six hundred dollars worth in on night I believe but I can't remember to tell you much about it Eliab step'd off a wharf in a very dark place and come near breaking his arm it has been lame ever since
Completed

I'm afraid E is a little too daring. I guess he does in regard to detecting Rumsellers xc what hardly any other person would or could do without giving more offence he is very efficient but very smooth & good natured about it. He seems contented & happy but his health is not very firm Sam'l thinks that E has not gain'd as much the past year as his expenses have been--will not continue with Mr. Haskins I think another year says he has all the labor & but half the pay. Eliab has not been here since a year ago last July
Charles is getting his harvesting done earlier than usual, has got his crops all in, his corn more than half husk'd, some plowing done, & has been doing some to the house and shed, chambers finished all but plastering..means to paint outside this fall
The little boy are well Charlie wishes me to tell you that he is most six years old...and that he wants you should come here & bring your baby--our baby is very smart & very high tempered indeed she is very knowing for 10 months old she'll climb up stairs get into her chair & rock & sing bye bye - ask her what the birdy say & she 'll crow like a little rooster
And Lucy thinks she's got the very best baby "there is" & so I suppose you do. How I do long to see your little one may god bless you & keep you from all harm & bring you all back in his own good time to your affectionate Mother
Completed

Milo Mother Nov 23-1853
Du Quoin Dec 10, 1853
Milo Nov 23rd 1853
My Dear Son
I have written two letters to you within the past week informing you that Charles & Mr. John [Gilman are preparing to go to Du Quoin. I write yet again because Charles wished you to know as soon as may he the bargain he has made with Gilman. SO that you may be all ready to set him to work
Charles wants to go and we are wanting? to have him cherfly? because we think it would be better for his health. He has had a hard cough every winter for 3 years we hope by going there he will get rid of it. He think it would be for his advantage to have Gilman with him and we all now rather he would have company on the way. He had considerable parley with Gilman but firmly agree'd to give him $250 this board for six month work commencing on the second Monday in December & pay his ordinary haveeling expenses from Bangor to Du Quoin. Since closing the bargain & making writings Charles is afraid he is unclear to much risk fearing you may not have work ready or wages will not be so high or something. C says Gilman is a good work man he did our little meeting house all of it is an excellent framer. Says he will work for unclear and if sick will make up the time & Charles can have
Completed

all he can make out of him if it is five dollars a day he shall be satisfied
I had a litter from Lucy this evening she writes that Margaret Crosby died last Sunday
She says that E & Maria have talked considerable about about going to unclear but are getting off the notion of it. She don't want to go & we are afraid the journey would be to hard for at this time of year (she's a frail thing I guess) But I ant E should go on some accounts I think it might be some unclear to you (I very much fear you are taking to much upon yourself) and I should feel better to have him with Charles & last but not least I think his health might be better to be there during the winter
Notwithstanding I do feel anxious about your health and Netties I am afraid you are both working to hard do be careful of your health
How glad I shall be & truly thankful I hope when you can come home again and see your Mother
How I do want to see that little one who does he look like give him many kisses for me but don't love him too well he is unclear
Don't wait till Charles gets there before you write all about A is anxious to know whether he is given Gilman to much Nov 24th
Completed

brother M. Brownville & Milo Jan 7 1854
Du Quoin Ill. Jan. 21, 1854
is a clever pious capable woman but from what I ha e heard said of her think she may be tho' kind hearted &c rather inclined to the Slam bang or Smash about & not so careful & economical as Aunt Conant  they have 5 children Smart forward & healthy now? I guess - Sam'l has been unfortunate had a great deal of sickness - when he first started in life he got married & bought a farm all in a hurry - without due consideration his Mother thought. He got in debt his Father gave him 2 or 3 hundred dollars to get him out he afterwards to better his condition swapt (sic) farms & got in debt again which his Father has seem'd to consider an unpardonable sin & he has firmly held back & determin'd he would not give or lend him & considering what he has done for unclear name S. has some reason to feel bad about it - it is also a burden of grief to his mother - I do not know, but I suspect that he is hard press'd & perhaps in some danger of losing his Farm Tis possible the feeling that he cannot expect much sympathy or help from his Father or Hervy has induc'd him to think of going away & I fear it will very much distress his Mother. I have made a long story of it, & it is mostly guesswork
I doubt not that Charles will be very comfortable and happy with you - But he has had a sad time indeed, & a very hard time in consequence of the Sickness & Death of Mr. Gilman - besides the disappointment & frustrating his plans about work  But he can probably be useful to you & a benefit to himself in some capacity or other - I us'd to think he had the talent or ability in him for a good "Boss" but if he has it has lain dormant so long I dont know how he would manage  But I believe there is more of him than some folks think there is
I have often thought that he & you too lack self confidence  not quite
Completed

ready enough to step forward and take the place that might belong to him - It is a trait of the Stevens Characters & he has it from the Riches, also
To Dear Ettie I would say keep up good Courage the cold weather may do great thinks for her health had better wean the baby in April & come east and spend the next summer I dont know how Isaac can bear it to be left alone but probably it will be best tho' perhaps he can come a while in the warmest of the weather Dulvign (?) Mayo - well thats a good name How I wish I could take the dear little fellow in my arms
I suppose Charles is with you ere now & has heard from home too Albina has written a letter Directed to Du Quoin before I came away I suppose she will keep him inform'd of all the news - that Mr. unclear name has hir'd out with Sam'l & therefore did not help get up any road Mr. Bumps did not have the oxen. Sam'l will take them into the woods & I fear will or rather & know he does want them before they'll get up road enough - Netty became very lame they call it Sprain on her leg would not answer Sam'l's purpose he tried to swap her off but could get no more than $60, for her tis thought she may get over it after a while So he concluded to take my advice & not put her off at that price but take her back to the farm  Uncle Mark think they can make out to have keeping enough with some damag'd Hay that Sam'l has at the unclear barn - And S. has bought Mr. Russell name? horse for $150,
The School at the corner commenced the 14 of this month James board, at an house I dont know whether Charlie goes  his cough had not got well when I came away I expect to go home again in a week or two & stay a while and then go to Bangor a spell - I wish I could take Charles with me but Lissie is there & perhaps will be till Spring
Completed

expensive journey with a baby - I am sorry for you "but then it is nothing to California - Suppose you were to be gone 3 or 4 years - Why you have not been four months from your family yet" and you have only one Child to leave & C. has three & what adds exceedingly to all the rest with Albina is she has the care of housekeeping - family affairs &c. &c. She does feel very much troubled & distressed says her heart will break - finally I do suppose & I believe we all do that C ought to have come home last Spring - whether it will do for him to come now on account of his health I dont know. I doubt whether he ought to stay on account of the money he can get - for he could get wages enough here common Irishmen get here in Bangor from 2,50 to 300, a day & hard to get help at all - beside Charles expenses & losses are great at home - but the greatest consideration is that Albina takes it so hard I think that any other of my six girls would get along with it with more fortitude
It does seem as if Walter might consider it a good unclear that he has there even if he gets not much besides the board of himself & family as he has no other home & cannot work - Albina wrote me that "Charles gives him a good chance but she did not tell what
It does seem also as if Albina might brace herself to endure "the care & trial" of C.'s being gone a while longer & perhaps she would rather than have him come just as the cold weather commences & make him sick
ever loving Mother
Completed

Bangor Aug 27th/54
My very Dear Boy, I will just inform you that you have a little niece born Saturday morning Aug 26th, 7 1/2 oclock weighed 7lbs - both mother & baby not merely comfortable but smart Mainer unclear she could come down stairs this morning as well as not? - they think it is all owning to the use of sits bathes that she is so smart & well - but probably she will not feel so well a few days hence as she does now
We think Unclear is better but he has been better & unclear again to many times. he has not been so any day except he on two, when he was so sick 2 weeks ago but he would look back about & play a little- but cannot go alone - tho' he did a little when I first came here. Lucy has had a hard time this summer She looks now more like a ghost than a well person. She cannot unclear himself very much unclear unclear gets better I try to help her some but you know the mother is all in all for a sick child tho' he is very contented with me if she is not in sight
Completed

Mother wants me to write, but I have written so lately, than there seems to be unclear unclear to write but the news, and than Mother has written. The little damosel? up stairs is fat & plump, but I can by no means call her unclear - she is extremely modest and blushes unclear red all the time. I have written to Anna, Nettie to. We hope to heard from you soon. I had a dear letter from Nettie a day or two since. Poor little unclear does not seem so well today, but his teeth must come through soon. Tis sabbath, warm, sultry, P.P. feels miserably, as does Mother, as do I. Mr. Clarke from Hartford preaches this afternoon. The baby is a day & a half old & unclear says she could come down stiars as well as I could! She is very well. We are a little afraid we said too much in our last latter about Charles?
Completed

saying - it was only on unclear account, and we wrote to her to counteract it when she next wrote, if she feels to. Commencement this week - some of the strangers here today. Mr. Crane, from N.J. City preaches this morning. To write often because we feel greatly anxious for your health. With much love, Sister Lucy
Completed

Mother Bangor Sept 27, 1854
Oct 7
Sept 27 1854 Bangor
My Dear boy,  We have just received letters from you both  Dated Sept 17th  O how glad I am & how I thank you for writing so often - Albina sent me her letter too from Charles of Sept. 10th  I think Charles must have been puzzled & tried about coming home  Lucy & I were very sorry we wrote so much about his coming home  Should n't of if it had not been for Albina (she is not a suitable person to leave) it seems as if she has been comfortably situated except 2 or 3 weeks last month if it were not for this one idea (that seem'd to possess her mind entirely) "Charles must come home"  Walter has talked & I suspect pretended some about staying but inside I think he has wanted to stay all the while will perhaps ask more than C will be willing to give, he & George do have a very easy time
You speak about our going to Dunbarton how I wish we could I should really like to but it is not at all likely that Percie will be well enough before the weather will be to cold
Completed

me think he really is recovering now but is very feeble cannot walk or play about on the floor at all - it takes one of us all the time to take care of him - Lucy holds out unclear fully but she looks as if she could n't hold up her head or keep her eyes open - but she'll soon unclear as Percie gets well
Eliab is gone to Boston, he & P talk some about parting - I expect from their talk that they are to have very "tight" times about money - good many others in the same predicament - water so low not much sawing no freight for vessels &c. Rather bad for Eliab to be setting up housekeeping just at this time as it must take considerable money - he has been paying rent for his house (5'0,$ again) since the first of this month I believe expects to move from here in a week or two
Maria & baby getting along nicely  she expects her eldest sister to come and help her about "setting up" housekeeping and that her youngest sister will come and
Completed

spend the winter with her
Dont you think that Charles's health will suffer if he comes home just as the cold weather commences - he is needed at home to put things to rights & I should be very glad he is coming if it was not for the fear I have about his health
They will have done all the Harvesting I guess for there was very little to do  the dry weather and the frost I suppose kill'd the Corn and most of the Oats - Albina said Walter & George were cutting down the alders just below the knowls by that little old bridge for firewood - I told her that the 12, a month & six dollars for board that Georges labor unclear cost would buy more unclear than he would get in a month in that way
Walter has not calculated business as well and done as much work as I expected
Mr. Rivers boys talk strongly of going off west & I guess Mr. Kittridge will, to look & see how they like
Completed

Mother. Bangor Sept. 27, 1854
Dunbarton Sept 30, 1854
Bangor  Sept. 27th /54
My Dear Daughter
I feel that I owe an apology for not writing to you - I find myself more clumsy &, stupid about writing as I grow old - & when I am home especially I contrive to put it off on to Lucy as much as I can - If I could write, and could express my thoughts and feelings with as much ease & facility as you and Lucy can - I could better tell you how much I love & care for you & the Dear little Mayo - And how ardently I long to become more acquainted
But when I think of my absent ones and the Small prospect there is of my being with them much more and knowing their feelings their joys & their sorrows as I us'd to when they were all with me - My consolation is in the thought
Completed

that we may all meet in the "old mans Home" - a permanent home, where heart meets heart - where Sorrow and sickness and parting never come
O how thankful I ought to be (& I think I am) that I have such good children - all of them so good - How good & kind Isaac is about writing it is a great comfort to me - we had letters from him & Charles yesterday  Charles talks of coming home we shall expect him in a month or six weeks - I feel very much afraid he will be sick in consequence of coming so late in the season
Albina has worried so much about his coming home that he has concluded to come there is no doubt but that he wants to come enough but I believe he had thought it would be very much for his interest to stay till near Spring - I hope when Isaac comes you you & little Mayo come and stay a good long time  I do long so to be more acquainted with the baby  Mayo  I dont know but he is getting to be too smart to be
Completed

call'd a baby  I was greatly amus'd to hear about his driving the Turkeys &c  No doubt but he's his Fathers own Child
How I do wish we could go to Dunbarton but the dear little Percie is so feeble that we have have no reason to expect he could bear the journey this fall - Lucy holds out wonderfully - but she looks as if she could not hold her head up or keep her eyes open - Percie is nervous & excitable it takes one of us all the time & sometime both to take care of him  Lucy has been so perfectly devoted to him & Sam'l too that I have feard he would be taken away on that very account  God requires of his children the whole heart but he is longsuffering & generous  you are very good & kind on writing to me when you get such poor returns it is a favor & a great gratification to me to hear from you - any thing which concerns you is interesting for me to know
My love & respects to your dear Parents  I wish we could have the pleasure of seeing them
Completed

here and your Brother and sister also  We had a letter from Albina tuesday little Mary was a good deal better tho' not quite well - we expect Charlie to come here in a week or two to stay a while perhaps all winter or till I go home  I dont know whether I shall stay here all the winter or not -
Yesterday Mrs. Carlstin Jewet 2 names unclear and Miss Hannah Moore took tea with us   Eliab is gone to Boston  Maria and the little one are getting along nicely has not Eliab got a good wife? dont you love her I am sure I do & I wish I was more worthy of such good children as I have 
kiss the Dear little Mayo for me
your ever affectionate Mother
Completed

I wont have you go - We are getting along nicely at present  Caddie performs her part very well  I make out to get sleep enough while the Babe sleeps - The week that you were here & the 2 or 3 weeks before were very very hard for me  I wonder I did n't quite break down under it - But the generous (?) Promise is & will be fulfils - 'As the day is so shall thy strength be' I do not mourn I felt a solemn quiet resignation - Almost Joy that Dear Lucy, Suffering and conflicts are all over that she has arriv'd to that heaven where I hope to be & the time is short even if I should live to endure many days of pain & suffering in my turn all things are passing away they will soon be gone
Do write frequently I thank Nettie for her good letter receivd
Completed

last night - Lizzie Maye died Tuesday night was buried yesterday was deranged almost all the time she was sick
Lizzie stays here she commenced going to school this week
The Dear little Babe is not quite a (sic) well these 2 days past seems more feeble & languid sleeps a great deal but dint (sic?) take its food so well wakes a little and stretches & makes up all manner of faces  I hope it is not going to be sick
How I should love to see those little boys. The Twins will run alone by the time they are a year old wont they? I think that is pretty well for 8 months babies  It will be less work to take care of them when they can walk but you'll need your eyes about you then too
remember me to your Father Mother & much love to you all from your
Mother
Completed

Mother Bangor
Sept. 21 1836
Dunbarton
I thank you my dear good boy for your good long letter to me & to Eliab of 16th & Sam'l of the 18  O that I could do or say any thing to comfort you my Dear Children  Sorely afflicted indeed you are poor Nettie but let me remind her to be thankful that you are spar'd to her - from my own experience I can feel that the loss of all her dear children would be lighter than that - I shall feel very anxious till I hear that she is recovered  I have many fears too for your Mother Putnam she is so feeble  But those dear beautiful boys * feel deeply my own loss & feel it doubly in feeling it for you too - But let it serve to lessen the cords that bind us to Earth  & fix our thoughts more intently on that dear home where all tears are wiped away & the inhabitants shall no more say I am sick
I can hardly imagine where your sick have all been located - none up stairs I suppose?
Completed

I have been planning about Percies winter clothes but have done nothing as yet he wears his little baby dresses under his aprons but they are getting to be not warm enough  I shall have time enough to fit for him now the Dear little baby is taken from me  I did look for a great deal of comfort & satisfaction in taking care of it but it has gone to its mother & doubtless is ten thousand times better off than it could be in this world of sin & sorrow
I am expecting to go to Milo with Percie to stay a few weeks probably in a week or 10 days - Sam'l & Lizzie stay at Eliabs the while  I hope to hear from you often while there
much love to all the folks from
your ever loving Mother
Completed

Mother  Milo Maine
Oct. 20th 1856
Dunbarton
Milo Oct. 20th 1856
My Dear Children
I thank you very much for Netties good letter of Oct. 7th  what warm weather we have had almost all this month  I have been helping Albina was today Tis more than I have done at that business in all the time that I have been gone from here  I find my strength is very much less than it was last summer  I have grown older but my health is very good for a person of my age I think  I have been here 2 weeks today  begin to feel quite at home again - I always feel a little discontent (?) & uneasy a few days when I first come home after being gone for some time - Percie is just as happy & contented as a child could be ever since he has been here he & Mary agree very well
Mary is now a very smart & good little girl. The children very often speak of Mayo  Dear little Mayo how much I did love him - hardly an hour in the day but he has been in my thoughts since I have been here - But let us rejoice that he and the
Completed

other dear ones that have gone are safe in our Fathers house in the blissful presence of Him that died that we might live
I hope the dear little Wilder will soon have his teeth through & be well  I should think that change of air and more yet change of scene would benefit your health - James is here yet is very steady and attentive to his business he has not been home since last April  The little boys have improved in their behavior I think. Charlie has rais'd by his own labor 2 bushels of potatoes about one bushel of Beans & some carrots &c. He prepares to devote a part of his revenue to benevolent purposes is going to buy some litt e Backs (?) for distribution & feels the importance of his transactions considerably he gives Joseph a share of his profits tho' he says he so lazy that he did nt help him hoe but little
Josie is a smart strong boy to work when he has a mind to - Albina's health seems quite as good as it was last summer notwithstanding she is 3 months along She has done all her housework except that Mrs Calors (?) help'd her work a few weeks in the summer
Completed

I feel sorry for Mary She is a real good affectionate little girl - but she gets scolded so much & for what she can hardly help doing - She teases her Mother a unclear words to let her be a boy yesterday she got on a hat & one of the boys old jackets & so we call'd her John  her Mother went to the door a while after & found she had an axe chopping away on a stick of wood & call'd to her to come away  she said my name is n't Mary I'm John, cant I chop if I'm John
I have delay'd sending my letter to the PO by one mail hoping to get a letter from Isaac before sending it - Have been cutting out Jackets for Charlie & Josie out of Charles wedding coat got them both out nicely after some contriving with Albina to help  There is work enough here to do Albina has a lot of sewing to do  I unclear a chance to send to the PO this minute So good bye
with much love to you all
Mother
